title: Wikiwand - Energy medicine
description: Energy medicine is a branch of alternative medicine based on a pseudo-scientific belief that healers can channel "healing energy" into a patient and effect positive results. The field is defined by shared beliefs and practices relating to mysticism and esotericism in the wider alternative medicine sphere rather than any sort of unified terminology, leading to terms such as energy healing or vibrational medicine being used as synonymous or alternative names. In most cases there is no empirically measurable energy involved: the term refers instead to so-called subtle energy. Practitioners may classify the practice as hands-on, hands-off, and distant where the patient and healer are in different locations. Many schools of energy healing exist using many names: for example, biofield energy healing, spiritual healing, contact healing, distant healing, therapeutic touch, Reiki or Qigong.
cleaned_text: Energy medicine Pseudo-scientific alternative medicine / From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Dear Wikiwand AI, let's keep it short by simply answering these key questions: Can you list the top facts and stats about Energy medicine? Summarize this article for a 10 years old Energy medicine is a branch of [alternative medicine](/en/Alternative_medicine) based on a [pseudo-scientific](/en/Pseudoscience) belief that healers can channel ["healing energy"](/en/Energy_(esotericism)) into a patient and effect positive results. The field is defined by shared beliefs and practices relating to mysticism and esotericism in the wider alternative medicine sphere rather than any sort of unified terminology, leading to terms such as energy healing or vibrational medicine being used as synonymous or alternative names. In most cases there is no empirically measurable energy involved: the term refers instead to so-called [subtle energy](/en/Subtle_energy). Practitioners may classify the practice as hands-on, [[1]](#cite_note-Times-1) hands-off, [[1]](#cite_note-Times-1) and distant [[1]](#cite_note-Times-1) (or absent) where the patient and healer are in different locations. Many schools of energy healing exist using many names: for example, biofield energy healing, [[2]](#cite_note-mdanderson-2) [[3]](#cite_note-springerlink-3) spiritual [Reiki](/en/Reiki) [[6]](#cite_note-Reiki_Practice-6) or [Qigong](/en/Qigong). [[2]](#cite_note-mdanderson-2) Reviews of the scientific literature on energy healing have concluded that there is no evidence supporting clinical efficacy. [[7]](#cite_note-7) [[8]](#cite_note-Abbot-8) [[9]](#cite_note-9) [[10]](#cite_note-ernst2006-10) [[11]](#cite_note-Pittler-11) [[12]](#cite_note-TrickOrTreatment-12) The as implausible; [[13]](#cite_note-GistLubin-13) [[14]](#cite_note-AAQM-14) [[15]](#cite_note-stenger-15) [[16]](#cite_note-Kruglyakov-16) research and reviews supportive of energy medicine have been faulted for containing methodological flaws [[17]](#cite_note-McCaslin-17) [[18]](#cite_note-Pignotti-18) [[19]](#cite_note-19) and [selection bias](/en/Selection_bias), [[17]](#cite_note-McCaslin-17) [[18]](#cite_note-Pignotti-18) and positive therapeutic results have been determined to result from known psychological mechanisms.
